abstracts.cdata!:
The project was rated as highly
            satisfactory. The road improvement component was implemented
            at approximately the estimated cost, yielding the estimated
            rate of returns, in line with appraisal estimates. The Fund
            for National and Regional Roads (FNRR), achieved
            considerable institutional improvements, and the Customs
            Administration in Macedonia, stands at the forefront within
            the region, in recognition for its customs reform process.
            Regardless of success, the following lessons learned are
            suggested: 1) Although project design and its complexities,
            should remain within the project's stated objectives, a
            realistic overall implementation assessment, defines a
            highly satisfactory achievement, vs. a troubled one, with
            various difficulties stemming from inappropriate project
            design. 2) Implementing government agencies are the primary
            determinants for timely completion of individual project
            components. Thus, FNRR's experience, contributed to the
            timely civil works completion. 3) The government strong
            commitment should convey that sense of ownership, paramount
            for prioritizing specific activities. Conversely,
            flexibility on the part of the Bank, would convey a sense of
            willingness to consider particular circumstances, such as,
            the high percentage approval of retroactive financing, a key
            factor in easing implementation, and ensuring a timely completion.
